results.title: A Negroni.. Sbagliato...
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of Drawing Funny's YouTube post "What's Your Favourite Drink? A Negroni.. Sbagliato.. With Prosecco In It"
results.brief_description: When HBO posted a video of House of the Dragons stars Emma D’Arcy (Princess Rhaenyra Targaryen) and Olivia Cooke (Queen Alicent) discussing their favourite drinks, the internet collectively lost its mind. Video impersonations, memes, club mixes and queer tributes ensued on TikTok, Instagram and Twitter as the “stunning” broken negroni moment went viral.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

When HBO posted a video of House of the Dragon stars Emma D’Arcy (Princess Rhaenyra Targaryen) and Olivia Cooke (Queen Alicent) discussing their favourite drinks, the internet collectively lost its mind. Video impersonations, memes, club mixes and queer tributes ensued on TikTok, Instagram and Twitter as the “stunning” broken negroni moment went viral. The rhythm of the back-and-forth exchange has been adopted by social users as a template to prove a surprising point or argument that gradually escalates.
description_for_label: When HBO posted a video of House of the Dragon stars Emma D’Arcy (Princess Rhaenyra Targaryen) and Olivia Cooke (Queen Alicent) discussing their favourite drinks, the internet collectively lost its mind. Video impersonations, memes, club mixes and queer tributes ensued on TikTok, Instagram and Twitter as the “stunning” broken negroni moment went viral. The rhythm of the back-and-forth exchange has been adopted by social users as a template to prove a surprising point or argument that gradually escalates.

results.title: A Year to Remember 1953
results.brief_description: Collection of newsreel footage which made up Australia’s history in 1953 - Deaths of Stalin and Queen Mary - Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II - US Vice President Nixon visits Australia - Testing of the Jindivik at Woomera - Mt Everest conquered by Sir Edmund Hillary and Tensing - Anzac Day in Korea - Exchange of POW’s - Express train crash in New Zealand - Davis Cup wins by Lew Hoad and Ken Rosewall - Ben Hogan wins British Open … and much more. Rated: G

Rated: G

results.title: #hairforfreedom
results.brief_description: International celebrities including Oscar award-winning Juliette Binoche and Marion Cotillard have taken to social media to express their solidarity with protests in Iran, ignited by the death of 22-year-old Mahsa Amini while in the custody of Iran’s morality police for violating the nation’s dress code. The videos, which document women symbolically cutting off their own hair, have been compiled and posted on an Instagram account “soutienfemmesiran” — which translates as “support women in Iran” – using the hashtag #hairforfreedom.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

International celebrities like Oscar winners Juliette Binoche and Marion Cotillard have taken to social media to express their solidarity with Iranian protestors, following the death of 22-year-old Mahsa Amini while in the custody of Iran’s morality police for violating the nation’s dress code. The videos, which show women symbolically cutting off their hair, are compiled on Instagram account soutienfemmesiran (support women in Iran), using the hashtag #hairforfreedom.

Social media’s reach allows online communities to collectively condemn actions across the world – supporters may not be able to be there physically, but social gives them a voice – tethering protestors on the ground with human rights advocates and activists, resulting in support, as the video below shows, that can result in causes being advanced on traditional media channels.
description_for_label: International celebrities like Oscar winners Juliette Binoche and Marion Cotillard have taken to social media to express their solidarity with Iranian protestors, following the death of 22-year-old Mahsa Amini while in the custody of Iran’s morality police for violating the nation’s dress code. The videos, which show women symbolically cutting off their hair, are compiled on Instagram account soutienfemmesiran (support women in Iran), using the hashtag #hairforfreedom. Social media’s reach allows online communities to collectively condemn actions across the world – supporters may not be able to join protests, but social gives them a voice.

results.title: A Record of pre-school play
results.creator_credit: Australian Council for Educational Research and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: These children are representative of 100 who commenced primary school in Carlton during 1951. Some children had attended the Lady Gowrie Pre-School Centre, some came from other kindergartens and creches and some had not attended any pre-school centre. The children were assembled for two weeks at the end of 1950 to study their vocabulary and this film was made of their unrehearsed and undirected activities. Photography by Rodney Power.
